user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_response_entry:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
add_response_entry (struct MHD_Response *response,
                    enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                    const char *header,
                    const char *content)
{
  size_t header_len;
  size_t content_len;

  if (NULL == content)
    return MHD_NO;

  header_len = strlen (header);
  content_len = strlen (content);
  return add_response_entry_n (response, kind, header,
                               header_len, content,
                               content_len) ? MHD_YES : MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function add_response_entry:
static bool
add_response_entry_n (struct MHD_Response *response,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      const char *header,
                      size_t header_len,
                      const char *content,
                      size_t content_len)
{
  if (NULL == response)
    return false;
  if (0 == header_len)
    return false;
  if (0 == content_len)
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\t', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, ' ', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\r', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\n', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\r', content_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\n', content_len))
    return false;

  return MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ (response, kind, header, header_len,
                                           content, content_len);
}
...
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_add_response_header (struct MHD_Response *response,
                         const char *header,
                         const char *content)
{
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (header, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONNECTION))
    return add_response_header_connection (response, content);

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (header,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_TRANSFER_ENCODING))
  {
    if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (content, "chunked"))
      return MHD_NO;   /* Only "chunked" encoding is allowed */
    if (0 != (response->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_TRANS_ENC_CHUNKED))
      return MHD_YES;  /* Already has "chunked" encoding header */
    if ( (0 != (response->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH)) &&
         (0 == (MHD_RF_INSANITY_HEADER_CONTENT_LENGTH & response->flags)) )
      return MHD_NO; /* Has "Content-Length" header and no "Insanity" flag */
    if (MHD_NO != add_response_entry (response,
                                      MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                      header,
                                      content))
    {
      response->flags_auto |= MHD_RAF_HAS_TRANS_ENC_CHUNKED;
      return MHD_YES;
    }
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (header,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE))
  {
    if (0 != (response->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_DATE_HDR))
    {
      struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *hdr;
      hdr = MHD_get_response_element_n_ (response, MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                         MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE,
                                         MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                           MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE));
      mhd_assert (NULL != hdr);
      _MHD_remove_header (response, hdr);
      if (NULL != hdr->value)
        free (hdr->value);
      free (hdr->header);
      free (hdr);
    }
    if (MHD_NO != add_response_entry (response,
                                      MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                      header,
                                      content))
    {
      response->flags_auto |= MHD_RAF_HAS_DATE_HDR;
      return MHD_YES;
    }
    return MHD_NO;
  }

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (header,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_LENGTH))
  {
    /* Generally MHD sets automatically correct "Content-Length" always when
     * needed.
     * Custom "Content-Length" header is allowed only in special cases. */
    if ( (0 != (MHD_RF_INSANITY_HEADER_CONTENT_LENGTH & response->flags)) ||
         ((0 != (MHD_RF_HEAD_ONLY_RESPONSE & response->flags)) &&
          (0 == (response->flags_auto & (MHD_RAF_HAS_TRANS_ENC_CHUNKED
                                         | MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH)))) )
    {
      if (MHD_NO != add_response_entry (response,
                                        MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                        header,
                                        content))
      {
        response->flags_auto |= MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH;
        return MHD_YES;
      }
    }
    return MHD_NO;
  }

  return add_response_entry (response,
                             MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                             header,
                             content);
}
...
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_add_response_footer (struct MHD_Response *response,
                         const char *footer,
                         const char *content)
{
  return add_response_entry (response,
                             MHD_FOOTER_KIND,
                             footer,
                             content);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Selected fragments are those where control-flow or precondition assumptions may make code paths unreachable or lead to undefined behavior that effectively prevents later code from executing: 

- add_response_entry: it checks only content for NULL but immediately calls strlen(header) without checking header for NULL. If header == NULL the strlen call is UB and will prevent reaching subsequent checks/calls; any checks inside add_response_entry_n that assume a non-NULL header may therefore be unreachable in that invocation. This fragment should be investigated to confirm whether header can be NULL and whether this leads to unreachable code or undefined behaviour.

- add_response_entry_n: this function contains a sequence of early returns and uses memchr on header and content pointers. These checks assume header and content pointers are valid for the given lengths; if callers (such as add_response_entry) do not guarantee those preconditions, some of these checks may never be reached (or may cause UB before they can run). Investigate whether the preconditions for header/content non-null and consistent lengths are always satisfied; if they are always satisfied by design, these checks might be redundant/never-taken (potentially unreachable) or, if not, they may be insufficient.

- The DATE-header removal block in MHD_add_response_header: it asserts that hdr is non-NULL (mhd_assert (NULL != hdr)); depending on build (assert enabled vs disabled) the behavior differs: in builds with assertions enabled the assert may abort the program, making the subsequent free() calls unreachable; in builds without assertions, the code proceeds and frees hdr. This differing behaviour makes reachability conditional on build configuration and should be investigated for unintended unreachable code or inconsistent control flow.

Why other fragments were not selected:
- The explicit header-name branches in MHD_add_response_header (TRANSFER_ENCODING, CONTENT_LENGTH, default path) contain ordinary conditional returns and fall-through paths; none contain code syntactically placed after an unconditional return in the same block, nor do they exhibit immediately-obvious impossible branches given the provided code. They perform runtime checks and then either return or call add_response_entry; these are normal control flows and do not by themselves indicate unreachable code.
- The simple wrapper MHD_add_response_footer merely forwards to add_response_entry and does not contain extra code that could be unreachable.

Investigating the selected fragments should uncover whether any branches are truly unreachable (or made unreachable by UB or build-time assertions) and whether control-flow assumptions match the intended design.
